review.title: An approach to multi-agent planning with incomplete information
review.abstract: Multi-agent planning (MAP) approaches have been typically conceived for independent or loosely-coupled problems to enhance the benefits of distributed planning between autonomous agents as solving this type of problems require less coordination between the agents' sub-plans. However, when it comes to tightly-coupled agents' tasks, MAP has been relegated in favour of centralized approaches and little work has been done in this direction. In this paper, we present a general-purpose MAP capable to efficiently handle planning problems with any level of coupling between agents. We propose a cooperative refinement planning approach, built upon the partial-order planning paradigm, that allows agents to work with incomplete information and to have incomplete views of the world, i.e. being ignorant of other agents' information, as well as maintaining their own private information. We show various experiments to compare the performance of our system with a distributed CSP-based MAP approach over a suite of problems.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: This paper presents a universal MAP model that is capable of dealing with a variety of MA planning problems under incomplete information. Ability to define incomplete views of the world for agents allows us to deal with real problems, from inherently distributed domains - functional or spatial - to problems that handle global and centralized sources of information.The MAP solution process is a POP-based refinement approach that combines planning and coordination on an iterative basis, while for each agent only the information that is visible to the planning unit is obtained. This POP approach centers around the step-by-step creation of a common solution plan for the MAP task and highly demonstrates the solution of cooperative distributed planning problems.
